For Release Weekend Editions Dec. 30-31
Another Wild Week For Heating Oil, OJ Futures
DOC.TEXT: A shot of OJ with a heating oil chaser was the New Year's drink of choice in the commodity pits. Orange juice futures rallied this past week after a damaging freeze in the Florida citrus belt, and heating oil for January delivery finished with a record high. On other markets, precious metals futures nosedived, most grain and soybean futures fell, and livestock and meat futures were little changed. Frozen concentrated orange juice for delivery in January soared 21 percent during the holiday-shortened, four-day trading week, settling Friday at $1.6565 a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange compared with $1.37 a week earlier. The contract jumped 16 cents on Tuesday alone as traders returned from the long Christmas weekend to reports of widespread damage to the Florida orange crop. Buying pressure eased on Wednesday, when profit-taking took the January contract down nearly 3 cents. But the rally resumed Thursday from news that Brazil, a major supplier of orange juice to the United States, was suspending juice exports until next week, when an official estimate of the Florida damage is expected. Analysts said Brazilian imports could increase by 20 percent because of the Florida freeze. They said Brazilian officials are probably trying to decide whether to raise the prices of their orange juice. Futures prices jumped again Friday amid forecasts for a return to normal temperatures in Florida this weekend. A warmup would hasten the falling and rotting of freeze-damaged fruit and make it more vulnerable to spoilage. ``Quite frankly, for some growers in Florida, this has been a disaster,'' said Bert Ruiz, a vice president of Balfour Maclaine Futures Inc. On the other hand, he said, speculators who bought the market prior to the Christmastime freeze ``were paid handsomely.'' The contract for January delivery of home heating oil expired Friday at a record high of $1.06 a gallon the New York Mercantile Exchange compared with 81.74 a week earlier, a 30 percent gain. Just one month ago, January heating oil was trading at about 62 cents a gallon. Jay Klopfenstein, head of Norwood Securities Inc. in Chicago, called the market's gains ``a once-in-a-decade type of movement.'' Analyst Peter Beutel of Elders Futures Inc. described the December rally as ``one of the most spectacular bull moves in heating oil of all time.'' The rally was largely linked to the unusually cold weather in recent weeks, which caused shortages of home heating oil on the cash market. The problem has been most severe in the heavily populated Northeast, where this December has been among the coldest ever. January heating oil rose sharply on Tuesday and Wednesday, then retreated Thursday after hitting $1.02 a gallon early in the day. The market seemed to have peaked. But buyers roared back on Friday and bid the price up to $1.06 by the close, reflecting uncertainty over next week's weather. The late rally raised speculation that the market will continue to surge when trading resumes next week.

Gold and silver futures prices fell sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting the withdrawal from the market of investors who had bought heavily during late October and November amid the startling political changes in Eastern Europe. The execution last week of Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and the surrender to the Vatican of ousted Panamanian strongman Manuel Noreiga seemed to ease investor fears about heightened international tensions, analysts said. Traders also were disappointed that the Soviet Union has not announced plans to back its currency with gold, as some experts had expected, said Peter Cardillo, commodity trading adviser with Josephthal & Co.

The soybean market again led most grain futures lower as growing conditions for the Brazilian soybean crop continued to improve. Warmer temperatures in the Great Plains and forecasts for above-average precipitation in that region next week weighed on the wheat market, where traders are keeping a close watch on conditions for the winter wheat crop.

Cattle and hog futures were little changed in a week of light, uneventful trading. Pork belly futures rallied after four weeks of losses in reaction to a monthly Agriculture Department report showing smaller-than-expected frozen belly stocks.
